The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members in accordance with Article 10 of the NATO Treaty. Congress finds that countries in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members in accordance with Article 10 of the NATO Treaty. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, as well as promoting economic stability and security in other countries like Slovakia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Bulgaria, Albania, Moldova, and Ukraine. In 1998, Congress emphasized the importance of admitting emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to NATO, beyond just Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. This was outlined in the European Security Act of 1998. The European Security Act of 1998 emphasized the importance of enlarging NATO to include emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe beyond Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. Congress stated that Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria would also contribute significantly to NATO's goals. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO. Congress declared that Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria should also be invited to become full NATO members upon meeting all relevant criteria. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO with the expectation of further invitations to nations willing and able to meet membership criteria. At the Washington Summit of the NATO Alliance in April 1999, a declaration was issued stating that further invitations would be extended to nations willing and able to meet membership criteria, with no European democratic country excluded from consideration. At the Washington Summit of the NATO Alliance in April 1999, NATO pledged to welcome new members that further the principles of the Treaty and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. No European democratic country fulfilling the Treaty's objectives will be excluded from consideration. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague, Czech Republic, to decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance in the next round of NATO enlargement. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, several countries in Central and Eastern Europe declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several Central and Eastern European countries declared cooperation in seeking NATO membership. In June 2001, a speech in Warsaw, Poland further discussed this goal. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all Central and Eastern European countries in a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001. President George W. Bush supports NATO membership for all Central and Eastern European countries, emphasizing the importance of security, freedom, and equal opportunities for new democracies in Europe. He rejects using nations as pawns and vows not to compromise the fate of free European peoples. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized the importance of NATO remaining open to all of Europe's emerging democracies during a speech in Detroit, Michigan in 1996. He stated that NATO's doors should not close behind its first new members and that no nation should be used as a pawn in the agenda of others. Clinton also rejected compromising the fate of free European peoples and called for advancing the cause of freedom at the Prague Summit. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized NATO's openness to all of Europe's emerging democracies during a speech in Detroit in 1996. He stated that NATO should remain open to new members and rejected the idea of a gray zone of insecurity in Europe. SEC. 3. DECLARATIONS OF POLICY. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of the NATO Alliance as expressed in previous acts and declarations, endorsing the vision of further enlargement articulated by Presidents George W. Bush and William J. Clinton. The NATO Alliance's vision for further enlargement was endorsed by Congress, following previous declarations by Presidents George W. Bush and William J. Clinton. The Alliance urges NATO allies to work towards realizing this vision at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, along with other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 designates Slovakia, along with other countries in Central and Eastern Europe, as eligible to receive assistance. This includes Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria. The President can also designate other emerging democracies in the region for assistance under the program. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 designates emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe, including Slovakia, for assistance under the program. The President can also designate other countries in the region as eligible for aid. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for fiscal year 2002: 
- $6,500,000 for Estonia
- $7,000,000 for Latvia
- $7,500,000 for Lithuania
- $8,500,000 for Slovakia
- $4,500,000 for Slovenia
- $10,000,000 for an unspecified country on a grant basis.
